comments.body: "Bounds of the default integer" -> "Bounds of the default integer on 64-bit platforms"

Good pick up. Although it's also not *always* correct as a C `long` on Windows only has 32-bits:

    Python 3.6 (64-bit) interactive window [PTVS 15.9.18254.1-15.0]
    >>> import platform
    >>> platform.architecture()
    ('64bit', 'WindowsPE')
    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> np.iinfo(np.int)
    iinfo(min=-2147483648, max=2147483647, dtype=int32)

maybe -> "Bounds of default int on this system"?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +285,289 @@
    >>> np.iinfo(np.int) # Bounds of the default integer on this system.
    iinfo(min=-9223372036854775808, max=9223372036854775807, dtype=int64)
    >>> np.iinfo(np.int32) # Bounds of a 32-bit integer
    iinfo(min=-2147483648, max=2147483647, dtype=int32)

comments.body: single backticks and no space between the `:ref:` and the content to make it a link

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +282,286 @@NumPy provides `numpy.iinfo` and `numpy.finfo` to verify the
minimum or maximum values of NumPy integer and floating point values
respectively ::

    >>> np.iinfo(np.int) # Bounds of the default integer on this system.

comments.body: the `numpy.power`, `numpy.iinfo` and `numpy.finfo` should **not** have `:ref:`, they should just be `single-back-tick content single-back-tick`.  I am not sure which domain is the correct one to get the links to appear, but `:ref:` apparently is not it. I tried this by doing `(cd ..; pip install .); make clean; make html` in the `doc` directory, and then `firefox build/html/user/basics.types.html` to view the result. The `pip install` is needed since the changes are part of the docstring picked up by `autodoc`, so the docstring (and therefore numpy) must be installed in the python used to build the docs

> I am not sure which domain is the correct one to get the links to appear, but :ref: apparently is not it

The correct domain is `:obj:`, but using no domain also works
I've removed the ``:ref:``'s entirely. That should make it simpler to read anyway. I've also rebased the commits to keep the history neat.
